content.description:
Pass two bolts on on the far right of the wall, clip the chains on the mid anchor, then pass another bolt and follow broken cracks to the top. 





Far right of the main wall

Gear to 1.5‚Äù

The second route on this wall from the left side up the terraced hill. Follow the second mostly vertical crack line to the top of the wall. Crux is near the top.

Tunnel Rock far left (up the terraces).
Standard rack.

Kevin's book calls this a 5.8, Marc's calls it a 5.9, so I went in-between. Feels more like a 5.8 to me.After the crack it winds around arete to the right and then finishes toward the left.The direct start with the 2 bolts is 10c and pretty scary getting to the 2nd bolt with ground fall potential. Center of the face, obvious hand crack leaning to the right. Standard rack, with doubles in hand to fist size if unsure of leading at the grade.
Bolted anchor

Thought this deserved it's own entry since it only shares the last few moves with the original line. I thought this was a much better and more sustained line - climbs the best part of the original route while skipping the easier climbing before the crux. 
  
 Low, distinct crux after clipping the second bolt, then follow thin hands left, hands up and fingers right before meeting up with the crux mantle of the 5.8 original line.  
  
 The crack climbing is 5.9-ish. The slab crux is given 10c by Bourdon, but it might be easier if you're 6 feet tall.

On the west wall of Tunnel Rock, following two low bolts (within the first ten feet) into cracks. The (climbers) leftmost line of bolts at the crag.
2 bolts, then gear from yellow C3 to blue C4. Chains at the top.

The first route done on this wall. On the left side, up terraced hill. Zig zag route with the crux being the left ward finger traverse near the top.After the hand crack start there is a right leaning traverse, and then the left crux traverse, if you go straight up before the right traverse it is a 5.8 variation. 2nd route in from the left, the first is a 5.7 crack standard rack to 3". The crux takes small cams. Use long slings to help with rope drag.
Bolted anchor

hand crack on far left.

up slope to far left end.
standard rack to 3", shares anchor with Go for Broke.

Climb the start of Tunnelman, then follow 4 bolts left up the airy ridge. 


4 bolts and a few cams

climbs.name: The Power of Leverage
climbs.fa: H Duty, E Olson, D Roberts (2013)

content.description:
Climb the steep right leaning hand crack 10 meters to the left of the tunnel. Then follow the line of 3 bolts just off to the left of the Noonday Ridge arete. The start is burly and can seep for awhile.  
  
 Shares an anchor with Noonday Ridge.

10 meters to the left of the Tunnel.
3 Bolts, standard rack, chains at the top

Basically an easier and less excellent right-hand variation on the direct start of Easy Skankin'. Face climb past 2 bolts, plug a bit of gear then join up with the splitter finger crack up to the mantles of Easy Skankin'. To the right of Easy Skankin' is a set of two bolts up a thin face to some splitter cracks. This is the direct start to Easy Skankin' (aka Queasy Crankin') and offers some pleasant climbing.

Keep going around the corner and you'll see another 2 bolts with more obvious face holds. This is Sunstroker. 2 bolts, gear to 1".

The route starts with low angle easy moves before getting steeper about half way up.

Gear to 2". Anchors with rap rings on top.

An alright route on fingers to hands. Bouldery start leads to straightforward jamming.

It's pretty close to the tunnel, on the left side. Slants to the right with a big block feature sticking out at chest/eye level. Technically in the "Vandalarium", though I have no idea why they should be considered seperate crags.
Single rack is fine, rap rings at the top.

This is the last little crag at the end of the trail with the tunnel over on the drippy right side. 
 This was really overgrown a few years back. I am guessing that when Robin Barley and friends where here in 2008 it got the makeover.
